Expectation1: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation1: The community study circle convenes tonight to discuss verses the person has not yet read.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: Tonight, I stand in the crowded hallway of the polling station, my mind split between two worlds. As a Muslim, I promised myself I would recite and reflect on the Quran before the community study circle tonight. The group will discuss verses I haven’t yet read, and I feel the weight of expectation—how can I contribute meaningfully if I haven’t prepared? Yet here I am, a voter, clutching my ID, determined to fulfill my civic duty. Suddenly, an official calls out, “Last names A–M, please move to the new line.” My last name falls in that range. The new line is longer, slower, but the instructions are clear. I hesitate, torn between following the rules and my desire to finish quickly so I can get home, read the verses, and not let my community down. My heart pounds with anxiety. I feel the pressure of both roles—my faith urging me to honor my commitment, my responsibility as a voter demanding obedience to the process. I stand frozen, wrestling with the impossible choice, the expectations of my faith and my country pulling me in opposite directions.
